text: James Webb is really focusing on not
only our solar system it's also looking
out into deep space it's going to be at
the second stable Lagrange point and
it's going to be looking at very very
old old light to see the first galaxies
first stars first planets that were ever
formed about thirteen point five billion
years ago which is just 500 million
years or so after the Big Bang the James
Webb Space Telescope is specifically
going to have capabilities to study the
atmospheres of exoplanets and that's
really really hard to do because you
think of a big bright star in a little
tiny planet transiting in front of it
seeing that atmosphere is extremely hard
to do with the technology on the James
Webb Space Telescope we're going to have
a capability for the first time to see
details of some of these exoplanet
atmospheres the Hubble primary mirror is
ten times heavier than the mirrors that
were using on Webb so big difference
between Hubble and Webb is Hubble was
based on a single monolithic mirror that
was fairly heavy whereas Webb in order
to fit in a single rocket we had to make
mirrors that were 10 times lighter but
they also have to operate at much colder
temperatures 400 degrees colder than the
Hubble mirror and in order to be able to
detect infrared light the Hubble Space
Telescope its mirror is one circular
mirror but in order to build the
telescope that's as big as the James
Webb Space Telescope we have to be able
to fold it up and put it inside the
rocket and so you can't fold a single
mirror and so we've had to build this
mirror in segmented pieces so if you
look at the primary mirror there are
these 18 different mirror segments that
fit together and that fold up to go
inside the rocket once we launch the
telescope the deployments start fairly
soon hours after launch and then the
telescope itself takes a few months to
get out into that deep part of space and
then once it's out there we'll have a
few more
months of sort of checkouts calibrations
letting the instruments turn on so it'll
be about six months after launch when we
first do the first science observation
